title: Michael Hudecheck
text:
I am a first-year Postdoctoral Research Associate at the University of St. Gallen School of Management’s Institute of Responsible Innovation. My current research focuses at the intersection of societal grand challenges, organizational theory, and entrepreneurship, with a particular focus on incorporating novel methods and data sources into empirical research.
My job market paper, which is under revise and resubmit at a Financial Times 50 ranked journal, was presented at the Academy of Management Annual Meeting and the Babson College Entrepreneurship Research Conference, where it was selected for the Best Paper Proceedings.
I completed my Ph.D. in Management at the University of St. Gallen with distinction in Fall 2023 (GPA 5.7/6). My earlier research on exploring the economic and social implications of the COVID-19 pandemic was awarded the University of St. Gallen’s Impact Award.
As an American citizen married to citizen of a European Union member state with Swiss permanent residence, I am authorized to work in the United States, European Union, and Switzerland.

title: Research
text:
Late Stage Working Papers
Hudecheck, Michael. Informal Entrepreneurship, Adversity, and Social Field Theory: A Cross-Cutting Cleavages Perspective. Presented at the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2023).
This late stage manuscript, presented at the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2023), investigates the ecological determinents of informal entrepreneurship, with a particular focus on how gender, ethnicity, and urbanization promote informal venturing among disadvantaged populations. It combines a custom dataset of urbanization and social activity derived algorithmically from European Space Agency Sentinel 2 multispectral imagery and National Aeronautics and Space Administration nighttime light emissions imagery with a longitudinal dataset of informal economic activity in Thailand. It is due to be submitted to a Financial Times 50 ranked journal with an expanded authorship team for review in Fall 2024.
Zachlod, Nina, Hudecheck, Michael, Siren, Charlotta, & George, Gerard. Using Satellite Data to Study Societal Grand Challenges. Accepted to the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2024).
This late stage manuscript, scheduled to be presented at the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2024), explores the role that emerging satellite-based data sources, such as multispectral imagery data, can play in organizational theory and management research. This manuscript was previously under revise and resubmit at Organizational Research Methods and is scheduled to be submitted to a UT Dallas ranked journal for review in Summer 2024.

title: Research
text:
Working Papers
Zachlod, Nina & Hudecheck, Michael. Power Relations and Resilience: The Implications of Calls for Justice Among the (Un) Resilient. Accepted to the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2024).
This working draft, scheduled to be presented at the Academy of Management Annual Meeting (2024), investigates how asymmetric power disparities among members of interorganizational alliances influences organizational resilience. It uses a novel dataset of several thousand meeting transcripts from small island developing states (SIDS) at the United Nations to explore how less powerful alliance members leverage messaging to influence resource allocation decisions. It is scheduled to be submitted to a Financial Times 50 ranked journal with an expanded authorship team for review in Winter 2024.
